Detailed Description

Class representing a 8-byte (64-bit) version number.

This class was added to the SDK for DAZ Studio 4.0 to make it easier to work with 64-bit version numbers and to facilitate compatibility with the old 32-bit version numbers.

Version numbers are typically displayed to the user as short version strings, e.g. 4.0, or long version strings, e.g. 4.0.0.0.

The version number consists of 4 components: The Major version number, the Minor version number, the Revision number, and the Build number. This is displayed in the following order: Major.Minor.Revision.Build.

In DAZ Studio, version numbers are typically stored as 64-bit unsigned integers with 16 bits for each number. This means that each number has a valid range of 0-65535. The most significant 16 bits are the Major version number, the next most significant 16 bits are the Minor version number, the next most significant 16 bits are the Revision number and the least significant 16 bits are the Build number. So, a packed version number in hexadecimal notation might look like: 0x1111222233334444ull where 1111 is the Major version number, 2222 is the Minor version number 3333 is the Revision number and 4444 is the build number.

It is recommended that this class and the provided version number macros be used when possible to reduce confusion when dealing with version numbers in code.

This class provides all the numerical comparision operators (<, >, <=, >=, ==, !=) to make it easy to compare version numbers without directly using the packed value, or the individual components.

DzVersion DzVersion::fromString ( const QString &  versionStr,
bool *  ok = NULL 
) [static]

Parses a version string into a version number.

Parameters:
versionStr A string representation of the version number in the form "N.N.N.N"
ok If not NULL, this will be set to true if conversion was successful, or false if conversion failed.
Returns:
The version number that was created from the string.

unsigned int DzVersion::getVersionNumber32 (  )  const

For backwards compatibility with old 32-bit version numbers - this function should only be used if absolutely necessary. It is highly recommended that all functionality be ported to the new 64-bit version number system. Using this function will result in inaccurate version numbering if one of the version numbers is greater than 255.

Returns:
A 32-bit packed representation of the version number.
QString DzVersion::getVersionString (  )  const
Returns:
A string containing the Major and Minor version numbers separated with a dot, e.g. "4.0"

Returns:
true if the version number has been initialized, otherwise false.
